previous_statement: COUNTING ROOTS IN C^+ VS C^-: EXACTLY ONE IN C^+. From Step 1.5.2.3, ALL n roots of f are non-real (f has no real roots). From Step 1.5.2.4, the sum of imaginary parts is Im(1/c) > 0. Now we use a CONTINUITY/DEFORMATION argument. Consider the family f_t(w) = p'(w) - n(alpha + i t beta) p(w) for t in [0, 1], where nc = alpha + i beta with beta < 0. At t = 0: f_0(w) = p'(w) - n alpha p(w) is a REAL polynomial of degree n. Its values at lambda_i are f_0(lambda_i) = p'(lambda_i) (real, alternating sign), so by IVT f_0 has exactly n-1 real roots (one in each interval (lambda_i, lambda_{i+1})) plus one additional root. The additional root is also real (since f_0 is a real polynomial with all coefficients real, and non-real roots come in conjugate pairs; n roots total with n-1 accounted for leaves 1, which must be real since complex roots pair up, requiring an even number; so all n roots of f_0 are real). At t = 1: f_1 = f, which has NO real roots (Step 1.5.2.3). As t increases from 0 to 1, the n real roots of f_0 must leave the real axis. Since f_t has complex coefficients for t > 0, roots can leave the real axis without pairing. However, roots move continuously with t, and the total count in C^+ is: #{roots with Im > 0} is a continuous (hence constant) function of t ONLY when no root crosses the real axis. But roots DO cross from R to C^+ or C^- as t increases from 0. The correct counting: at t = 0, f_0 is real, so roots are either real or come in conjugate pairs. All n roots are real (as shown). At t = 0^+, the n real roots split: some move to C^+, some to C^-. By the Vieta formula at general t: sum of roots = 1/(alpha/(n) + i t beta/(n)), and Im(sum) = -t beta / (n |(alpha + i t beta)/n|^2 * ...). Actually, more directly: at t = 1 we have all n roots non-real with Im(sum) > 0. The n roots that were real at t = 0 have moved into C^+ union C^-. Since the total Im(sum) > 0, there must be MORE roots in C^+ than in C^- (weighted by their imaginary parts). But we need the exact count. CLEANER ARGUMENT VIA WINDING: Consider f(w) = (-nc)(w^n - (1/c) w^{n-1} + ...) = (-nc) prod_{j=1}^n (w - w_j). The product of all roots = (-1)^n * (constant term of f) / (-nc). The constant term of f is f(0) = p'(0) - nc p(0), which involves specific values. Instead, use: f(w) = -nc p(w) + p'(w) = -nc [p(w) - p'(w)/(nc)]. The polynomial p(w) - p'(w)/(nc) = p(w) - (1/c) G_p^{unnorm}(w) where G_p^{unnorm} = p'(w)/p(w) * p(w)/n... this is getting circular. DIRECT ARGUMENT: Since f has no real roots (Step 1.5.2.3), and all n roots are non-real, and c is NOT real (Im(c) < 0), the polynomial f has complex coefficients. Non-real roots of complex polynomials need NOT come in conjugate pairs. However, we can count the roots in C^+ using the argument principle applied to C^+ directly.
new_statement: CONCLUSION: ALL ROOTS IN C^+. Combining Steps 1.5.2.3 and 1.5.2.4: the polynomial f(w) = p'(w) - nc p(w) has degree n and therefore exactly n roots in C (counted with multiplicity). By Part A (Step 1.5.2.3), none of these roots are real. By Part B (Step 1.5.2.4), none of these roots lie in C^-. Since C = R union C^+ union C^- is a disjoint partition (where C^+ = {z : Im(z) > 0} and C^- = {z : Im(z) < 0}), all n roots of f must lie in C^+. Therefore the equation G_p(w) = c has exactly n solutions, all in C^+. In particular, at least one solution lies in C^+, which guarantees the existence of the subordination function omega_1 in Step 1.5.3. QED.
